channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Lancet Study Calls for Action to Prevent Millions of Newborn Deaths
item.description: India has the highest number of newborn deaths in the world — nearly 780,000 babies under 28 days old die every year, with many deaths happening within 24 hours of birth, according to a series on newborn survival in The Lancet that was published Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women waiting to see a doctor at the government hospital near Uragahalli village in Karnataka state.

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows Killing of Palestinians on ‘Nakba Day’
item.description: Security-camera footage obtained by a rights group appears to show the fatal shooting of two young Palestinians during a demonstration in Beitunia, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Killings Heighten Tension Around Egyptian Election
item.description: Three riot police officers trying to break up a student protest died in a drive-by shooting on Tuesday as early overseas voting results favored the military’s former leader.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Video Captured Killing of 2 Palestinian Teenagers at Demonstration
item.description: In the video, released by a human rights group, neither teenager appeared to be engaged in provocative behavior when shot by the Israeli military.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Satellite Firm to Release Data on Missing Malaysian Jet
item.description: Inmarsat confirmed that it would publish in the coming days a full record of the communications received from the plane the day it disappeared.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: China and Russia Fail to Reach Agreement on Gas Plan
item.description: Despite predictions that political concerns would help push a deal through, Beijing and Moscow remained unable to close the gap on price.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China attended a dinner in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: From Cameron, a Sense of Justice Delayed but Achieved
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron praised the terrorism conviction in New York of a radical British cleric but regretted the long extradition process.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Bosnia’s Other Calamity
item.description: In the face of catastrophic floods, a divided nation’s leaders fail the citizens.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD P. JOSEPH and SRECKO LATAL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Veterans Protest U.S. Involvement In Asia
item.description: The demonstration in Lotus Flower Mountain Park in Shenzhen followed an outburst of violent anti-Chinese protests in Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Mr. Putin’s Far-Right Friends
item.description: He could hardly wish for better allies than these anti-European Union agitators.
item.dc:creator: By JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Turkey’s Preventable Tragedy
item.description: The ruling party knew the Soma mine wasn’t safe, but it blocked an investigation.
item.dc:creator: By OZGUR OZEL

item.title: For U.S. Companies That Challenge China, the Risk of Digital Reprisal
item.description: Standing against Beijing, or even alerting foreign governments to trade issues, can carry serious repercussions.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: People’s Daily Apologizes for ‘Gutter Oil’ Report
item.description: The website of the Communist Party-controlled newspaper said it had confused a chemical factory and a foodstuffs factory in its article about illegally recycled cooking oil, known as “gutter oil.”
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Pistorius to Face Psychiatric Assessment
item.description: The examination was ordered after a defense witness in Oscar Pistorius’s murder trial testified that the athlete suffered from a generalized anxiety disorder.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Charges of Chinese Cyberspying, Wanted Posters Included
item.description: The five members of China’s military accused of hacking against American companies are at the top of the F.B.I. “Cyber’s Most Wanted” list, but little has been revealed about them beyond their names and aliases.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wanted posters identified the Chinese military personnel the United States has linked to cyberespionage.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Rare, Partial Victory in Saving Remnants of Old Beijing
item.description: In a first, a Beijing resident has won protected status for what remains of two sites of historical value from the city’s cultural authorities.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Cui Jinze stands below the hanging lotus gate at No. 33 Lingjing Lane. The empty rectangles along the top of the gate show where thieves removed carved panels in January.

item.title: Fukushima Workers Fled Plant After Accident Despite Orders
item.description: A previously undisclosed interview with the plant manager described the panic among workers at the most dire moment of the nuclear disaster.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Defense Statement on the U.S. Cyberspying Indictment
item.description: In a statement, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense condemned the United States indictments of five Chinese military officers on charges of hacking into commercial networks to steal corporate secrets.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Imposing Martial Law, Thai Military Denies Plans for Coup
item.description: Military leaders in Thailand, whose prime minister was removed earlier this month, urged the public to stay calm, saying they intended to “bring peace to the beloved country.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Pedestrians strolled past armed Thai soldiers guarding a government building in Bangkok after martial law was declared.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Reporters on ‘Gutter Oil’ Series Assaulted, People’s Daily Says
item.description: The Communist Party news organization said its reporters were attacked and robbed of their cameras and cellphones while investigating “gutter oil,” waste cooking oil that is illegally reused.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: One researcher estimated that as many as 10 percent of restaurant meals were cooked with tainted oil.

item.title: U.S. Cites End to C.I.A. Ruses Using Vaccines
item.description: A top White House official has pledged that the C.I.A. will no longer use vaccination programs as cover for spying operations.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: General Declares Martial Law Across Thailand Amid Paralyzing Protests
item.description: The head of Thailand’s army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have blocked elections to “stop their movement.”
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Pedestrians strolled past armed Thai soldiers guarding a government building in Bangkok after martial law was declared.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: U.S. to Bolster Search
item.description: The United States has reached an agreement with Nigeria to share some intelligence to bolster the search for more than 200 girls kidnapped by the group Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: Heroin Seized
item.description: Nearly 1,700 pounds of heroin was smuggled into the Netherlands last week hidden in a shipment of Iranian raisins.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Separatists Free Hostages
item.description: Separatists in northern Mali have released about 30 civil servants held since Saturday after an attack on a regional governor’s office in Kidal.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
